key_points: At Oxford High School, a shooting incident resulted in four students killed and seven others wounded, including a teacher.
The alleged shooter, 15-year-old student Ethan Crumbley, is accused of firing at least 30 shots in a premeditated attack.
Crumbley faces charges as an adult, including first-degree murder and terrorism, with his lawyer entering a not-guilty plea on his behalf.
His parents, James and Jennifer Crumbley, were charged with involuntary manslaughter and arrested after missing their arraignment.
James Crumbley purchased the gun used in the shooting shortly before the incident, and Ethan posted about it on social media.
School officials were warned about Ethan Crumbley's concerning behavior, including a search for ammunition online and a disturbing drawing found on his desk.
Despite the warnings, Ethan was allowed to return to class the day of the shooting with the gun in his backpack.
During the shooting, Ethan allegedly walked the hallways of the school, shooting students in a methodical manner before being detained by police.
Students and teachers barricaded themselves, using objects as potential weapons for self-defense during the shooting.
Ethan Crumbley's parents contacted authorities and their son via text upon realizing the situation, but he was already in police custody by then.
spokespersons: Zander Cumbey (Student at Oxford High School)
Tim Willis (Lieutenant, Oakland County Sheriff's Office)
Tim Throne (Superintendent, Oxford High School District)
